Server.description: Development of server-side code. Examples: Ruby/Rails applications, WFG processes, Drupal migrations

milestones.summary: Works within current applications following existing patterns
signals: Works on stories that can be delivered in a short timeframe
Makes minor changes to existing applications
Pair programs to fix well-documented bugs and deliver well-documented features
examples: Updates a Rails view to show existing data
Removes data from a Drupal migration
Edits a question in a WorkflowGen form

milestones.summary: Extends current applications with new features, creates new examples of existing applications
signals: Applying lessons leaned from previous stories
Refactoring code to new patterns
Starts a new application from a template
examples: Migrates a Rails application to a new major release
Creates a new Drupal migration based on an existing migration
Adds new questions to a WorkflowGen form

milestones.summary: Implements unique features or applications
signals: Debugging and documenting novel problems
Designing applications with new feature sets
Integrates new applications with existing ones
examples: Creating a Drupal migration that uses a new data source
Designing a new WorkflowGen process that uses new parts of the tool
Debugging and patching a unique problem occurring in a Rails gem

milestones.summary: Leads the design and implementation of new applications
signals: Prioritization of a list of stories needed to deliver a new application
Sees steps to get from current to desired code
Delivers code that is honed by past experience and easily changed in the future
examples: Serving as Lead Developer for a new Rails application
Leading multi-step refactoring necessary to implement a new feature
Designing an application that can be changed to work with as-yet undeveloped code

Client.description: Development of client-side code. Examples: JavaScript applications, CSS, Accessibility, UI, UX

milestones.summary: Works within current client-side code following existing patterns
signals: Works on stories that can be delivered in a short timeframe
Makes minor changes to existing applications
Pair programs to fix well-documented bugs and deliver well-documented features
examples: Updates CSS classes used by elements
Edits Rails views to improve accessibility
Fixes misuse of Bootstrap competent names

milestones.summary: Extends current client-side code with new features, creates new examples of existing applications
signals: Applying lessons learned from previous stories
Refactoring code to new patterns
Starts a new application from a template
examples: Uses automated accessibility checks to ensure quality of work
Revising CSS code to work with latest Bootstrap release
Creating a new JS framework app based on an existing application

milestones.summary: Implements unique client-side solutions
signals: Debugging and documenting novel problems
Designing applications with new feature sets
Integrates new applications with existing ones
examples: Debug, document and fix a UX error that is browser specific
Evaluating new JS frameworks for use on upcoming projects
Build cross-application CSS/Asset libraries to give multiple applications similar tooling

milestones.summary: Leads the design and implementation of client side solutions
signals: Prioritization of a list of stories needed to deliver a new application
Sees steps to get from current to desired code
Delivers code that is honed by past experience and easily changed in the future
examples: Lead Developer for a new JS application
Leading a refactoring of a complex Rails' application view layer to meet accessibility guidelines
Writing a UX toolkit that the team can use in a wide variety of applications

Infrastructure.description: Development of infrastructure and operational code. Examples: Ansible, Capistrano, Splunk

milestones.summary: Works within current operational code following existing patterns
signals: Works on stories that can be delivered in a short timeframe
Makes simple configuration changes to services
Use well-documented automation tools and verify that they work
examples: Updates existing Ansible playbooks and runs them
Edits Splunk reports
Runs and verifies application deployments and database migrations

milestones.summary: Applying lessons leaned from previous stories
signals: Applying lessons learned from previous stories
Refactoring code to new patterns
Start operational reporting from a template
examples: Creates new playbooks based on existing playbooks
Updates an application to use a new major version of Capistrano
Delivers Splunk dashboards and notifications

milestones.summary: Implements unique operational and automation tools
signals: Implement and automate novel operational technologies
Designing new operational features
Integrate existing work to create new tools
examples: Writes playbooks from scratch for a new technology
Implements a new metrics/logging layer for an application
Aggregate application events into explorable Splunk dashboards and visualizations

milestones.summary: Leads the design and implementation of large-scale, highly-automated operational code
signals: Prioritization and delegation of stories needed to deliver a new application
Sees steps to get from current to desired code
Delivers code that is honed by past experience and easily changed in the future
examples: Co-ordinate multiple development teams to deliver consistent Application events that can drive automation
Leads effort to consolidate existing automation scripts into a single ChatOps application
Develops CI/CD tooling that can be used across multiple applications

Analysis.description: Working with stakeholders to gather requirements, decomposing features in to deliverable stories

milestones.summary: Effectively analyzes stories
signals: Discusses tightly-scoped features with stakeholders
Helps team judge upcoming work
Writes effective technical specs outlining approach
examples: Reviewing a story and any questions during a sprint planning meeting
Participating in a sprint planning meeting, doing story estimation
Outlining implementation steps on a whiteboard, following that plan until the feature is done

milestones.summary: Effectively iterates and balances work
signals: Uses iteration to quickly deliver and refine features with unclear requirements
Collaborates with stakeholders to explore their needs
Balances work between stakeholder needs and team constraints
examples: Demoing an unfinished story to get feedback
Scheduling a quick design meeting with stakeholders to flesh out unclear/unexpected requirements
Delivering a story meeting the current tests, without delivering extra code to satisfy possible future stories.

milestones.summary: Effectively delivers projects through a small team
signals: Organizes project to deliver highest business value early
Leads technical analysis to compare possible solutions
Manages upgrade to external systems and the systems that use them.
examples: Running sprint planning meetings with stakeholders during the course of a project
Creating spike branches and rubrics for judging the success of alternative approaches
Leading the analysis and testing of our apps as part of a PeopleSoft upgrade

milestones.summary: Effectively delivers projects through a large team, or with a significant amount of stakeholders or complexity
signals: Leads analysis and story breakdown for a complex application
Blends new, existing and 3rd party work to deliver features
Uses high-level requirements to scope and outline a project
examples: Reviewing requirement documents and writing a technical plan for the development steps necessary to complete
Researching, testing and implementing Kafka
Estimating and prioritizing work to deliver a new Rails application

Communication.description: Shares the right amount of information with the right people, at the right time, and listens effectively

milestones.summary: Communicates effectively to close stakeholders when called upon, and incorporates constructive feedback
signals: Communicates project status clearly and effectively
Collaborates with others with empathy
Asks for help at the appropriate juncture
examples: Writes a commit message that includes the context and reasoning for a change
Pair programs as both driver and navigator
Asks clarifying questions in a Pivotal Tracker story

milestones.summary: Communicates with the wider team appropriately, focusing on timeliness and good quality conversations
signals: Practices active listening and suspension of attention
Ensures stakeholders are aware of current blockers
Chooses the appropriate tools for accurate and timely communication
examples: Using one-on-ones to hear feedback on weak areas
Discuss roadblock in project stand up and collaborate with the stakeholder to resolve it.
Deliver a presentation (or write a blog) about a recent project

milestones.summary: Proactively shares information, actively solicits feedback, and facilitates communication for multiple stakeholders
signals: Resolves communication difficulties between others
Anticipates and shares schedule deviations in plenty of time
Manages project stakeholder expectations effectively
examples: Organizing Communities of Practice to reduce silos
Writing a technical roadmap document outlining the application's context and trade-offs
Leading sprint planning and retrospective meetings for a project

milestones.summary: Communicates complex ideas skillfully and with nuance, and establishes alignment within the wider organization
signals: Communicates project risk and trade-offs skillfully and with nuance
Provides a framework for team inclusivity and culture
Negotiates resourcing compromises with other teams
examples: Writing a long-term work plan that balances Director requests and other project needs
Leading project to formalize Ground Rules for meetings
Meeting with OIT team to outline our hosting needs and developing a plan for collaboration

Best.description: Embodies and promotes practices to ensure excellent quality products and services

milestones.summary: Follows established best practices effectively
signals: Uses TDD/BDD workflow for new features and bug fixes.
Follows best practice guides
Writes clear git commits and pull request descriptions
examples: Writing a failing test for a new feature before implementing the new feature
Using the Rails Best Practice guide to create a new Rails application
Following the Git message template in our Git Best Practices guide

milestones.summary: Expands use of practices to existing systems, suggests revisions to current practices
signals: Adding best practices to code that predates the practices
Helping the whole team follow our best practices
Identifying practices that are no longer working or necessary
examples: Adding a code linter to a legacy application
Thorough and empathetic code reviews, pointing out places where the code does not follow our practices
Discussing a unnecessary practice in a team retrospective

milestones.summary: Teaching best practices, researching and experimenting with new practices
signals: Documenting best practices and their purposes
Researches and develops new practices
Automating best practices
examples: Writing a new best practice guide for Rails
Release a CI tool to address a pain point discussed in team retrospectives
Developing a script that runs pa11y accessibility checks as part of our test suite

milestones.summary: Identifying areas in need of best practices, developing and documenting practices
signals: Leads project to update code that does not follow best practices
Introduces best practices that improve the entire team
Manages the introduction of multi-step processes
examples: Serving as Tech Lead for TFMS refactoring projects
Create weekly retrospectives and processes for continual improvement
Developing a roadmap to introduce an automated CI/CD pipeline

Community.description: Builds and supports community. Champions the team, department and University values

milestones.summary: Participates in UMN IT and ASR Community events
signals: Participates in team activities
Treats colleagues and clients with respect
Joins and participates in relevant groups
examples: Attending Code-People meetings
Inviting team to a lunch where everyone's dietary needs are met
Member of TechPeople Slack, offering help when available

milestones.summary: Expands the scope of UMN IT and other Community events, helping to build a more inclusive culture
signals: Represents ASR at events outside of the UMN IT community
Expands membership of UMN IT community
Evangelizes involvement in UMN IT community
examples: Completing the Equity and Diversity certificate
Find teams not attending Code People and invite them to attend; suggest talks that will attract a wider audience
Telling other UMN employees about benefits of hearing a talk or attending a meeting

milestones.summary: Organizes of UMN IT and other Community events, shaping a welcoming and inclusive culture
signals: Expanding options for Community involvement
Introduces new ideas in to the UMN IT Community
Advocates for changes to UMN Community
examples: Starting a new Community of Practice, or joining the committee of an existing one
Inviting an external speaker or trainer to campus
Scheduled windows-specific talks so that Windows devs would feel welcome at Code People

milestones.summary: Strategy for and leadership of UMN IT Community
signals: Finding communities not represented in UMN IT Community, making space for them
Mentoring new community leaders from under-represented communities
Advocates for Community involvement at the Director/Chief level
examples: Guiding the creation of a new Community Of Practice for Junior Developers
Leaving a Committee position so that others can take your place and grow into a leadership role
Present to IT Leadership about the value of Tech-People

Mentorship.description: Provides support to colleagues, spreads knowledge, and develops the team outside formal reporting structures

milestones.summary: Is mentored by peers, supports new hires, and conveys institutional knowledge as appropriate.
signals: Receives mentorship
Shares daily learnings with the team
Perform ad-hoc mentorship
examples: Learn Ruby with the help of a Mentor
Post new command-line skills in Slack
Help a teammate with a blocker they list in their daily standup

milestones.summary: Mentors people proactively, and guides people to realizations rather than providing the answer
signals: Takes time to explain concepts and best practices
Asks questions to illuminate concepts, rather than stating them
Remove bottlenecks within the team
examples: Introduce the WorkflowGen development process to a new team member.
Mentor a new employee through an Exercism track
Document and share knowledge about a gem you wrote solo

milestones.summary: Teaches small groups and contributes to mentorship outside of the team
signals: Allows others to lead efforts when it will help their development
Mentors developers outside of the team
Establishes mentorship plans within the team
examples: Ask another team member to deliver a story that you already know how to deliver
Participate in WIT's mentorship program as a mentor
Create and run a Code Smell study group

milestones.summary: Encourages people to mentor each other, and creates ways for them to do so
signals: Builds a framework for mentorship
Mentors those new to mentorship
Mentors groups
examples: Create a mentorship plan for a new employee
Assign mentorship role to new mentors, meet with them to help them improve
Organize and run a campus-wide coderetreat

Professional.description: Identifies skills that you want to improve, plans and implements how to improve them

milestones.summary: Addressing immediate development needs
signals: Plan to learn skill used on current project
Identify skills to learn based on observation
Completes and reviews short-term professional development
examples: Read Sidekiq documentation after seeing it used in SDP
Incorporate a vim technique you saw your pair use
Put a webinar on your IDP, complete the webinar and report back what you learned

milestones.summary: Uses recent experience to create plans to develop over the short to medium-term
signals: Review problems faced on recent work, develop plan to address
Short-term planning of skills to collaboratively learn
Complete and review medium-term professional development
examples: After having trouble with Rspec mocking, set aside time to read the Rspec book and review mocking strategies
Decide with a pair to learn about the Stimulus js framework before delivering a story that will use it
Create an IDP entry for learning about Agile Story Writing that incorporates books, webinars, etc. Complete the work and discuss with the team.

milestones.summary: Uses knowledge of past problems and future work to guide long-term development for self and for a small team
signals: Incorporate past and future work to plan development
Mapping out skills needed for a project team
Complete and review long-term professional development
examples: Based on past experience with WorkflowGen and knowledge of a upcoming WorkflowGen project, set aside time to experiment with new features of the platform
At the start of a Rails project map out technology and techniques that the team wants to use, determine a training plan so that the team is ready
Complete the Equity and Diversity certification and share your experience with the team.

milestones.summary: Prepares for unknown challenges and maps out long-term development for multiple people
signals: Development plans to address unknown future possibilities
Creating a long-term skill roadmap for multiple people
Complete and review multi-person, long-term professional development
examples: Set aside time to research Kafka as  a possible solution to data pipeline problems
Build a map of team skills, work with team members to fill gaps
Establish a goal of cross-training team on Drupal development, organize training and then assign work to reinforce the training
